Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2014 10:52PM AZ85048 wrote: Kuchenhexe - I have never heard of a BMX or MX without drains.  Because our bodies are all so different, my experience won' be the same as yours and yours won't be the same as someone else's.  In my case I had two drains (one on each side - but none for my node biopsy site) after BMX and they were removed six days post op.  But that's because my fluid output was next to nothing after four days.  They were a pain in the @ss not too mention painful if you move wrong, but very necessary nonetheless to prevent seroma.  You have to be very diligent about documenting the output every time you empty them.  The volume of output directly effects how long you have to wear the drains. Usually when the fluid volume is 30 ml or less consistently for a period of 24 hours, you can have the drains removed, but that also depends on your PS.  And by the way, I had no drains at all for my exchange.  But some people do... Your mother is very sweet to be thinking ahead, but there are other things you'll need more than a drain garment.  You can make do very nicely with a set of big old safety pins (the two or three inch kind) and some sort of lanyard for around your neck.  I just pinned my drains to whatever I was wearing or put them in the pockets of my robe.  You can also fasten them with the safety pins to a lanyard (or a couple of shoelaces tied together for that matter) and they can hang from around your neck.  Personally I would have been pissed to have spent money on a garment I only used for less than a week... but that's just me.  I don't know if you have a recliner, but if you don't, maybe ask your mom to rent you one.  (You can thank me later.)  Most of us slept in a recliner for more than a few days after BMX.  I think I graduated to my bed after about a week and then was propped up with a pillow under each arm and about a dozen pillows behind and beside you.  Hope that helps you a little.

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2016 06:49PM AZ85048 wrote: Pamjenn - Sorry to meet you under these circumstances, but welcome to BCO! The answer to your question isn't as black and white as one would think. First, you need to take a deep breath. We've all been right where you are; and yes, waiting IS the worst part of all of this... Once they have your pathology report and you've agreed upon a plan, things get a little easier. Generally, you'll have a follow up with your surgeon a few days after your surgery and the pathology report should be ready by then. However, I have read where some women were able to access theirs within 24 hours; so it all depends on the facility and your doctor. Just be sure to request a copy for yourself and start a book / or box for all of your medical records. Take someone with you to your appointments if at all possible, because they'll be throwing a lot of information at you hard and fast. It really helps to have someone else in the room either taking notes or listening intently. Because believe me, you won't remember half of what you're being told. None of us did. Good luck tomorrow and I'll keep a good thought for you!

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2014 05:14AM - edited Jan 11, 2014 05:15AM by AZ85048 Hi, Mindy,  I had a nipple sparing BMX in August with immediate reconstruction.  After a few months with TE (tissue expanders - the worst), I was able to have my exchange surgery the day after Christmas.  So a little better than two weeks out, I'm feeling good and more normal than I have in quite some time.  You'll have a hundred questions along the way.  We all did.  All you have to do is ask.   You can do this; really you can.  You're much stronger than you think you are.  Stay strong and let us know how it goes!  Additions for your list:  For the hospital: Sanitizing face wipes Eye drops Throat lozenges Chapstick Head band and ties Eye mask, ear plugs Back scratcher (if morphine makes you itchy) eReader/tablet (may need a hotspot if the hospital doesn’t have wi-fi) Headphones Flashlight or flashlight app for your phone Someone else will be rummaging in your bag to find the things for you. Make their life easier by putting the items in clear Zip Loc bags and labeling them for easy access.

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2014 07:20PM - edited Jan 20, 2014 07:59PM by AZ85048 MInaBee - So sorry you have to join us, but so glad you've found a great support system here at BCO.  I learned early on that it is so very important to take someone with you to those first appointments when everyone is discussing diagnosis / options.  It is such a help to have another set of ears in the room.  Let your sister go with you - she might be going because she doesn't know what else to do right now and it will help her understand as well.  Just something to think about.  Sending you a big hug and a little prayer!  Please let us know how you make out next week.

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2014 10:22PM - edited Feb 24, 2014 10:22PM by AZ85048 Terri001 - Here's the way the ratings works (liberated from Wikipedia): BI-RADS Assessment Categories are:  But you know what, if you give me enough time, I can pull up a few threads here on BCO where even though they were rated birads5, some people ended up BENIGN, so don't give up.  That biopsy on Friday will tell you exactly what you're dealing with and define where you go from here. If at all possible, take someone with you when you get the pathology results from the biopsy.  (And ask for a copy for yourself.)  Not necessarily because it will be bad news, but just so you have another set of ears in the room.  This is all a big emotional roller coaster and you'll want to know exactly what was discussed.  Sending you a huge hug and a bigger prayer...

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2014 07:27PM AZ85048 wrote: momto3boysaz - I just posted on your other thread.  In a DCIS diagnosis they usually include whether you are ER+ or - and PR+ or -.  All the answers will lie in the pathology report.  Be sure you get a copy of it when you're at the appointment.  I advised you in my other post to take someone with you on Thursday.  Also, stay away from Dr. Google, because in all actuality you don't know enough to research anything yet and you'll just scare yourself needlessly.  Please let us know how it goes on Thursday.....

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2014 07:12PM AZ85048 wrote: Luppie - I would see what they have to say at Mayo and go from there.  See how you feel in your gut about the doctor(s) which to me was a big part of the process.  Luckily for me, I had known my surgeon for years and trusted him completely.  We started with a lumpectomy during which they found even more reason for concern.  It was only then that I started to consider at MX as an option, and it was my choice to go with a BMX.  I am so glad I did and would make the very same choice again.  But take your time and don't feel rushed.  It's a big decision no matter what you choose to do. Also, I learned early on that it is a great idea to take someone with you to these kinds of appointments because (at least for me) my brain went into overload and there were things they said that I missed, but my friend was able catch.  Good luck and try not to worry too much.  You can do this!.

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2014 01:08PM AZ85048 wrote: kgruenhagen - Welcome to BCO!  Unfortunately, many of us on here have been faced with that very decision.  I can only speak for myself, but when faced with the diagnosis in one breast, I chose to remove the other for many reasons (I'll spare you the details).  Ironically, my 'good' breast was found to be nearly as diseased as the other one when they removed it, which is what we had guessed based on the fact that my 'original girls' always mirrored one another.  Do your homework and go with your gut.  You'll know what's right for you.  It's a big surgery and a big decision so you need to make peace with whatever it is you ultimately decide.  Good luck with whatever path you choose to travel!

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2014 08:41PM AZ85048 wrote: Beachgirl2 - Hi!  I had fibrocystic breasts for over 20 years and lumps would come and go.  The girls were always swollen and I wore a bra 24/7.  My point is that in those twenty years I had maybe four or five of those benign little cysts go rogue on me and get infected (from the inside).  They would get red and hot and sometimes protrude noticeably.  I still have never quite figured out how that happens...  I totally freaked out my PCP a few years back because he's never seen one before.  But I had.  The only thing to do was to have it aspirated and then immediate relief!  Just a thought....  Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: Swelling, pain and firmness in one breast Beachgirl2 Kicks

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2014 09:09PM AZ85048 wrote: Beachgirl2 - Not necessarily both breasts - I guess I was just lucky!    You can have fibrocystic breast disease in one or both breasts.  My breasts have always mirrored one another just because they seem to be so competitive!  And to be very clear, my diagnosis and surgery for bc had nothing to do with those cysts but now that I've gone through what I did, a big bonus was to get rid of the pain from those little suckers, believe me!
Posts.Title: Swelling, pain and firmness in one breast Beachgirl2 Kicks

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2014 01:11AM AZ85048 wrote: foxesnbutterflies - Welcome!  I can speak from my experience. Some twenty or so years ago I was diagnosed with a severe case of fibrocystic breast disease and had a few or as many as a dozen cysts in each breast at all times.  I slept in a bra every night during that time.  Over those many years, I had two that were biopsied, a half dozen or so that were aspirated, and the rest we left alone.  They were always very painful before and during my period, but they were also always benign.  Cysts are fairly common in women of a certain age, but very rarely are they a sign of BC.  Listen to your doctor as a stereotactic biopsy will give you the answers you're seeking and the aspiration will deflate the cyst and give you some relief.  Good luck to you and let us know how it goes for you!

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2014 12:39PM AZ85048 wrote: teaspoonofsugar - So sorry you're having a hard time - but you know what?  You're much stronger than you think you are!  A few months ago, I could have written your post.  I went through the same series of events back in July and August - the stereotactic biopsy (which was no fun at all - they had a very hard time because of the location deep in my chest) and placement of a marker, then the wire insertion on the morning of my excisional surgery and so on.  But you know what?  It was the only way to get definitive answers about what was going on with me - and that, to me, was worth it. None of it was very pleasant, but the fear in your mind is much worse than the actual procedures.  Try to stay calm and know that you're doing everything that needs to be done to get some answers.  The waiting and apprehension are a special kind of torture that we are all too familiar with.  Please let us know how you're doing so we can help to calm your fears.  You can do this!  Sending you a hug and a prayer...

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2014 12:25AM AZ85048 wrote: Ddkath70 - Usually you don't get specifics from a needle biopsy (which if I remember right is what you've just had).  I know that all I found out from my stereotactic biopsy was that I had DCIS and they wanted to perform an excisional biopsy to see what was going on in there.  The report was not specific at all for that one - very generic in the big scheme of things.  It was only after the excisional biopsy that I got my first pathology report and that's the one that states my ER/PR+ status and the existence of LCIS and ALH as well as multi focal DCIS and the fact that it was grade 3.  I didn't know any specifics prior to that one, so don't worry too much about stage and grade quite yet.
